title: What is a champion that when mastered will wreck havoc/What champion has a high skill cap
body: I've been trying to find a main and I used to main zed but he got boring and I'm now bouncing between ekko and irelia.Who should I try next I would like someone that is rewarding if you put time into the champion. If you have any Ideas just comment below and put the champion icon.

So is LB (easy to pick up hard to master) and new kat is also pretty tricky to manage all her daggers.
If you wanna try a marksman, draven is probably the most mechanically complex and rewarding

I'd say Jhin is more mechanically complex than Draven. All you have to remember when playing Draven is that your axes move in the direction you last moved in, so if you're engaging on someone, you just run at them and you'll automatically pick up the axes.

With Jhin, you have to plan ahead (with traps), and two (technically three) abilities are skillshots.

but with draven, you can get triple axes going and dropping an axe makes your DPS drop by a huge amount. He also doesn't automatically pick up the axes as they set a few steps behind the location he will walk towards. Jhin is more about deciding when and how to fight more than actually outplaying.
Why hasn't  {{champion:119}}  been mentioned yet? IMO, though i dont play him, best carry potential for your time investment right there.
He's a very good adc right now when paired with a strong support. Thresh/Leona/Bard synergize very well with him since they can really hold someone down. (Bard with his cc/slows/ult.)

Riven is a top laner that fits your criteria. Lee sin fits it for jungle, and Kat fits for mid lane. ADC wise, you'd be looking at Draven or Vayne. Yasuo could also fit in for top or mid.
Each of these champs have good strengths and clear weaknesses (Most often CC and ranged harass, with all of them either being Melee or low range). They are also all champs that have a very big distinction between bad, good, and amazing mechanics. You can always tell between a good and a bad riven, or a godlike riven who spent months to years of practicing mechanics versus a mediocre one who picks her up because "she's op" (Which, she honestly isn't). 
ALL of these champions can be extremely strong when played right, with their kits utilized to their fullest.

No one considers Gnar as a high-mechanic champion though and in my opinion,  he is harder than Riven or Yasuo and I'll explain why. He has to fill  A LOT of purposes in a game. In the early game, where he stays in lane, he is mostly a ranged champion, since he doesn't get MEGAGNAR often. Therefore, you need ADC mechanics, where you poke with Autos and your Q, and you have an escape on E and a 3-hit proc on W. That said, your AA range is only 400 (getting to 500 at level 18), which is the lowest of all ranged champions, making AA poking harder than all of them, thus requiring great positioning and decision making to avoid minion aggro and retaliation. Also, he doesn't have resistances and hp regen early, so avoiding all damage is essential.

Then, it's the bar management. Knowing when to engage depending on the stage of the game and the situation you are in is highly dependant on your rage bar. It's better to be Mini when 1v1ing, especially after level 9, but have to be Mega when a teamfight breaks out. All these need careful management.

Also, as Megagnar, you need to also do a lot of things. A good engage is the most critical, if you fail that, you are useless as Mega. Then, you have to follow up on the damage with your abilties, inserting an AA inbetween for maximum damage efficient, and all that is hard in the cluster that is going on. And then, once you turn back to Mini, you are still the guy who has to deal the damage as an ADC, requiring high-DPS mechanics, kiting, dodging etc.

And all of these are topped off by correct itemization, masteries and runes, mostly itemization. It requires a lot of forward thinking on how you are gonna itemize for Gnar. Most people go for Frozen Mallet first, but this can change into a Cleaver or even a defensive item, depending on the game. Even after you get your Maller and Cleaver, which is the most optinal and snowbally buy, you need to think if it's best to buy a GA because teamfights are gonna break out, or are you just gonna stay in lane and buy a more Armour or MR specific item. All these are relevant to all champions, but on Gnar, they are so much more important, because of the fact that he has to fill many roles (ADC, fighter, tank, initiator), and thus having the correct items at the correct time for the correct purpose can be crucial and requires a lot of forward thinking.

To be honest, just try and adjust to how the meta is shifting. There is no point trying to learn a high skill cap champion just because it's probably more rewarding. Focus on mechanics like csing, dodging, hitting skillshots, and on macro play like correct warding, map movement and pressure and every champion is simple good enough to carry everything.

If you want maximum performance, try to play whatever is best currently. Syndra was the best midlaner for a long time because of how she snowballed. Do that because it's the  most efficient. Of course, you can still play other things, but meta picks will probably pay off more.
